Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Impacts of Amazon Deforestation on Earth's Climate, Water, and Ecosystems: The Ebb of the Green Ocean?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal goal of this CAREER project is to understand and quantify the impacts of contemporary deforestation and projected future deforestation on climate, hydrology, and terrestrial ecosystems. A multi-scale analysis will be conducted with the following objectives (i) to determine how the size, shape, and organization of deforested areas alter atmospheric dynamics; and (ii) to study how the atmosphere communicates these changes to intact areas of rainforest, other parts of South America and other parts of the world. Climate vegetation feedbacks will also be analyzed. One of the deliverables of this project is an integrated framework for understanding how Amazon deforestation affects local, regional, and global climate, hydrology, and ecosystems. This framework will be extended to analyze deforestation in tropical Asia and Africa.

The research focuses on integrating research and education at the Middle School level. The primary goal is to bring improved understanding of Earth's atmosphere, land surface, and human elements of global change into the middle school classroom. A new teacher-in-service unit will be developed and organized under the aegis of QUEST, a professional development program with a 25-year track record of success and administered by Princeton University's Program in Teacher Preparation. Students will gain hands-on experience collecting and analyzing local weather station data, and will also be taught how to access Amazon-relevant data from the Internet. Students will present their work at a local science fair. This research will also support a graduate student. Thus this project has substantial broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 20% of the Amazon rainforest has undergone deforestation, or conversion of forested landscapes to short-statured vegetation. Such dramatic changes in the landscape affects how water and energy are transferred between the land surface and the atmosphere. Consequently, it has long been suspected that Amazonian deforestation would have implications for atmospheric variables such as rainfall and temperature.

Previous efforts to understand the atmospheric response to deforestation have focused either on very large scales (the hypothetical complete deforestation of the entire Amazon) or small scales (the deforesting of a kilometer-sized patch). Large-scale studies have generally led to predictions of precipitation decreases in the deforested region. In contrast, small-scale studies have generally predicted precipitation increases. What has been missing is an analysis of intermediate-scale deforestation (tens of kilometers). Increasingly, this scale of deforestation is the most typical one found in the southwestern Amazon today.

This project focused on understanding the hydroclimatic effects of deforestation on these intermediate scales. Using an array of observational datasets, we found that deforestation on intermediate scales has an effect that it is distinct from large- or small-scale deforestation. Specifically, intermediate scale deforestation generates a "dipole" pattern in cloudiness, precipitation, winds, and other aspect of the atmospheric state. Furthermore, we found that the observed patterns can be successfully simulated by atmospheric general circulation models. Such simulations helped us to attribute the observed changes in hydroclimate to deforestation. We have identified "surface roughness" as a key land surface property that determines the atmospheric response to intermediate-scale deforestation.

We have also used numerical models to understand how Amazonian deforestation may affect other parts of the world. We found that Amazonian deforestation, by changing the energy balance of the land surface, is able to create a heating anomaly in the atmosphere. Winds can carry this heating anomaly outside of the tropics. Certain extra-tropical areas were simulated to be more affected than others, but our numerical simulations have suggested a pathway whereby the western United States would experience precipitation reductions in response to complete Amazonian deforestation.

We have also investigated how tropical vegetation may respond to rainfall reductions that can accompany Amazonian deforestation. In particular, our work has identified a strong sensitivity of tropical tree cover fraction to precipitation variability. We have also used model simulations to illustrate how changes in precipitation regime may affect the recovery of trees and grasses from fires.

This project has provided training for two graduate students (1 female) and 6 undergraduates. Both graduate students have received their Ph.D. and are currently in postdoctoral researcher positions. The project also facilitated collaboration with a Brazilian group and the PI served on the Ph.D. committee of a University of Sao Paolo graduate student.

The research has been communicated in scientific publications, at international conferences such as those of the American Geophysical Union and the European Geophysical Union, at invited talks within the U.S., and at an invited talk at the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg, Germany. Data from this project have been made available through Princeton University’s public DataSpace repository.

An inquiry-based summer institute for grade 3-12 teachers was developed. This week-long institute on vegetation-climate interactions was offered for 3 years. Outreach was also conducted with local middle schools in both New Jersey and Indiana.
